prop.head.headtext: General Government Contracting Issues in the Cloud

head.headtext: Federal cloud acquisition strategies—Cloud terms of service (TOS) and end user license agreements (EULAs)

para.paratext: A cloud service provider (CSP) will often require a user to enter into a terms of service (TOS) agreement or an end user license agreement (EULA) (oftentimes collectively referred to as a “commercial supplier agreement” (CSA)) before authorizing use of the cloud software. CSAs are typically signaled by the following language:

[CLOUD PROVIDER] IS WILLING TO LICENSE THE LICENSED SOFTWARE TO YOU AS THE INDIVIDUAL, THE COMPANY, THE ORDERING ACTIVITY (IF AN ENTITY AUTHORIZED TO ORDER UNDER A U.S. FEDERAL GSA SCHEDULE CONTRACT), OR THE LEGAL ENTITY THAT WILL BE LICENSING AND UTILIZING THE LICENSED SOFTWARE (REFERENCED BELOW AS “YOU” OR “YOUR” OR “LICENSEE”) ONLY ON THE CONDITION THAT YOU ACCEPT ALL OF THE TERMS OF THIS LICENSE AGREEMENT (“AGREEMENT”).

(Emphasis added.) When the Government acquires commercial items or services, including cloud products or services, the terms must be consistent with those customarily provided to the public (i.e., commercial, and not unique to the Government). [1] At the same time, agencies may not agree to CSA terms that are incompatible with federal law, regulation, or practice.[
2] For example, many commercial supplier agreements contain indemnification terms that violate the Anti deficiency Act (ADA), which prohibits agencies from incurring obligations in excess of appropriated funds.[
3] The ADA provides that a Federal Government officer or employee may not:
make or authorize an expenditure or obligation exceeding an amount available in an appropriation or fund for the expenditure or obligation;

involve government in a contract or obligation or the payment of money before an appropriation is made unless authorized by law.[
4]

Officers who violate the ADA may be subject to administrative discipline or criminal penalties.[
5] Thus, contracting officers (COs) must “exercise caution in accepting a vendor's terms and conditions.”
[6]

headtext.bold: Agency counsel should review TOS agreements prior to signing

para.paratext:
Agencies should require employees to consult with agency counsel before agreeing to TOS agreements.[
7] Counsel reviewing a TOS agreement should verify that none of the clauses are incompatible with Federal law, regulation, or practice. Below are some examples of standard commercial terms that present enforcement issues in Government contracts.[
8]

Unrestricted, open-ended indemnity provisions have been found to be inconsistent with the ADA because, absent an express provision for reimbursement in an appropriation, “there can never be certainty that sufficient funds have been appropriated to cover the liability.”
[9] Consequently, in December 2013, the FAR Council released a final rule codifying the rule against open-ended indemnification clauses and other issues to which the government is required to take exception.[
10] The rule added a new FAR clause, which provides that “any clause requiring the Government to indemnify the Contractor or any person or entity for damages, costs, fees, or any other loss or liability that would create an Antideficiency Act violation (31 U.S.C. 1341)” is unenforceable against the Government and deemed stricken.[
11] This applies to all federal acquisitions—even micro-purchases.[
12] The rule also adds sections at FAR 12.216, 13.202, and 32.705 (Unenforceability of Unauthorized Obligations) to alert contracting officers that many IT supplier license agreements may contain indemnification clauses that are inconsistent with federal law and unenforceable.[
13]
An acceptable indemnity clause might be:

Indemnification, Liability, Statute of Limitations : Any provisions in the TOS related to indemnification and filing deadlines are hereby waived, and shall not apply except to the extent expressly authorized by law. Liability for any breach of the TOS as modified by this Amendment, or any claim arising from the TOS as modified by this Amendment, shall be determined under the Federal Tort Claims Act, or other governing federal authority. Federal Statute of Limitations provisions shall apply to any breach or claim.

Counsel should consider whether the employee opening the agency account has authority to do so.[
14] This is because EULAs are not binding on the Government unless “an authorized employee has entered into (or ratified) the agreement.”
[15] Generally, an authorized agent will be the contracting officer (CO) or an employee with actual, delegated authority. Additionally, the employee must be acting within the scope of his authority.[
16] For example, a CO's scope of authority is limited by the dollar amount in the CO's warrant.[
17] Therefore, a EULA with a clause indemnifying the provider for a sum that exceeds the amount in the CO's warrant will be invalid as a matter of law. Moreover, allowing individual users to “click to agree” is inconsistent with government principles of agency. Only warranted COs can “agree” to bind the Government.
An acceptable term to avoid ambiguity over the contracting parties might be:

Government entity : “You” within the TOS shall mean the Agency itself and shall not apply to, nor bind (i) the individual(s) who utilize the Company Site or Services on Agency's behalf, or (ii) any individual users who happen to be employed by, or otherwise associated with, the Agency. Company will look solely to Agency to enforce any violation or breach of the TOS by such individuals, subject to federal law.

Third-party terms can introduce potentially offensive provisions and remove the Government's ability to control the terms by which it may be bound. If the CSP plans to subcontract to a third-party licensor, the contractor should begin negotiations for the EULA riders as soon as practicable. Any provision that claims a contractor or reseller is not a party to the third-party terms and disclaims all responsibility, while the manufacturer may become a third-party beneficiary of the contract, must be stricken.
Clauses that protect an agency from third-party risks might be:

Limitation of liability : The Parties agree that nothing in the Limitation of Liability clause or elsewhere in the TOS in any way grants Company a waiver from, release of, or limitation of liability pertaining to, any past, current or future violation of federal law.

Assignment : Neither party may assign its obligations under the TOS as modified by this Amendment to any third party without prior written consent of the other; provided however, Company or its subsidiaries may assign the TOS as modified by this Amendment to a subsidiary or parent without written consent from the Agency provided that the successor assumes Company's obligations under the TOS as modified by this Amendment.

Clauses containing a choice of law provision or containing an arbitration provision raise a sovereign immunity issue. Both venue and the statute of limitations are usually mandated by federal law.[
18] The U.S. District Courts have concurrent jurisdiction with the U.S. Court of Federal Claims for claims under $10,000. Thus, an agency may agree to venue in a U.S. District Court located in a specific state. Arbitration clauses, however, must be stricken because GSA considers the Board of Contract Appeals to be an adequate, binding ADR alternative.[
19]
An acceptable clause on governing law might be:

Governing law : Any arbitration, mediation or similar dispute resolution provision in the TOS is hereby deleted. The TOS and this Amendment shall be governed by and interpreted and enforced in accordance with the laws of the United States of America without reference to conflict of laws. To the extent permitted by federal law, the laws of the State of [Company to insert name of state if one is mentioned in its TOS] (excluding [Company's state] choice of law rules) will apply in the absence of applicable federal law.

Any provision allowing the vendor to unilaterally modify the license terms or terms of service, with or without notice to the Government, must be deleted. A unilateral modification provision allows a vendor to introduce offensive terms in the future and removes the Government's ability to control the terms by which it may be bound. If included in the TOS, it would violate the contract formation rules under FAR 1.601(a) and 43.102. A clause that provides advance notice to the Government, however, does not violate the contract formation rules.[
20]
An acceptable clause for TOS changes might be:

Changes to standard TOS : Language in the TOS reserving to Company the right to change the TOS without notice at any time is hereby amended to grant You at least three days advance notice of any material change to the TOS. Company shall send this notice to the email address You designate at the time You sign up for service, and You shall notify Company of any change in the notification email address during the life of the Amendment.

An indemnification clause where the contractor commits to indemnify the Government, provided that it has sole control of the litigation, is also inconsistent with federal law.[
21] Only the Department of Justice (DOJ) is statutorily authorized to defend the Government.[
22] Some agencies, such as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), recognize that contractor indemnities are desirable and may agree to an indemnity clause that provides for appropriate consultation and allows the contractor to intervene in the proceedings at its own expense through legal counsel of its choice.[
23] However, if the contractor is providing cloud supplies or services under a commercial item contract for GSA or another agency through one of GSA's acquisition vehicles, such a clause will not be permitted.[
24]

A February 2012 memorandum by the Chief Information Officer (CIO) Council and Chief Acquisition Officers Council, Creating Effective Cloud Computing Contracts for the Federal Government, recommends that agencies “work with CSPs to understand what they require in order for Federal agency end-users to access a CSP environment and at the same time ensure that any TOS document incorporated into the contract is acceptable to the Federal agency.”
[25] The memorandum adds that, “if the TOS are not directly within the contract but referenced within the contract, the TOS should be negotiated and agreed upon prior to contract award.”
[26] Agency counsel should be part of the review process.[
27] If reviewing counsel finds clauses that are incompatible with federal law, regulation, or practice, there may be a duty to renegotiate the TOS or obtain another product with terms that are compliant with federal law.[
28]

Contractors should be aware of agency-specific rules regarding terms of service. For example, there may not be a duty to renegotiate TOS agreements if the contract is a GSA acquisition and it is for items containing “Commercial Supplier Agreements” as defined under GSAM 502.101. In February 2018, the GSA identified numerous commercial terms that are “automatically unenforceable, even if included in a commercial supplier agreement.”
[29] The accompanying guidance clarified that COs would not need to negotiate separately amendments to the commercial supplier agreements, unless objectionable issues were identified on issues not spelled out in the GSAM.[
30] Consequently, it is incumbent on a contractor to be familiar with the impact(s), if any, that class deviations or other agency-specific rules may have on its cloud contract.[
31]

The GSA's obligation to renegotiate inconsistent terms, as discussed above, applies only to fee-based products. In contrast, the GSA need not renegotiate the terms of free products, such as social media. The Government recognizes that agencies rely on digital media (e.g., social media, mobile, and business applications) to “engage with their customers and accomplish their mission.”
[32] Despite often being free applications, the standard TOS agreements, however, often contain problematic clauses.[
33] The Department of Justice concluded that a contracting officer violates the Antideficiency Act when he or she opens an agency account where the application is governed by terms that include an open-ended indemnification clause.

OMB's April 2013 memorandum advised agencies to conduct an inventory of all social media tools currently in use and maintain a record of all signed TOS agreements. OMB noted that it is the agency's responsibility to ensure all TOS agreements are in compliance with applicable law. Additionally, the agency is responsible for “complying with any reporting requirements pursuant to OMB Circular A-11 and taking all reasonable steps to mitigate the effects of any violation.”
[34] Where an agency has signed a TOS agreement that contains non-compliant clauses, the agency must renegotiate the TOS or obtain another product whose TOS do not include the open-ended indemnification clause.[
35] In the case of a renegotiated agreement, the agency CIO or other designated agency official must notify GSA of “the status of such renegotiation, the remaining next steps that the agency expects to take to complete the renegotiation, and a timeline for completing them.”
[36]

GSA leads the agency effort for negotiating acceptable TOS agreements, known as federal-compatible TOS agreements, between the Government and “providers of no-cost social and digital media products.”
Currently, the GSA and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) maintain lists of approved TOS agreements.[
37] DigitalGov lays out five steps for agencies interested in using one of these applications through an approved TOS:
Review the agency's social media policy and guidance regarding specific tools and branding.
See what free products and services with federal TOS agreements are available.
Work with the agency Point-of-Contact (POC) for social media tools and the agency general counsel for other tools and services.
If approved by the POC and the agency has signed a TOS for that tool, create an account.

Put accounts in GSA's federal-wide Social Media Registry.[
38]

David Gallacher and Townsend Bourne are partners in the Government Contracts, Investigations, and International Trade Group in the firm's Washington, D.C. office. Mr. Gallacher's experience involves a wide variety of litigation, administrative, and counseling issues related to federal procurement laws. His experience is extensive and includes complex litigation in federal court under the qui tam provisions of the False Claims Act, claims disputes before the Boards of Contract Appeals and bid protest actions. He regularly counsels both domestic and foreign companies on issues relating to compliance with a wide variety of government regulations.

Ms. Bourne's practice focuses on litigation and cybersecurity for government contractors. Her experience includes complex litigation in connection with the Contract Disputes Act and the False Claims Act, bid protest actions before the GAO and Court of Federal Claims, claims litigation before the Boards of Contract Appeals, investigating and preparing contractor claims, and conducting internal investigations. She also regularly advises clients on compliance with government regulations relating to cybersecurity, the GSA Schedule program, subcontracts and teaming agreements, procurement integrity, and organizational conflicts of interest.
Mr. Gallacher and Ms. Bourne would like to thank Melinda Biancuzzo for her invaluable work in helping to prepare this chapter.
